Citation: Y. Ishiki, "A characterization of metric subspaces of full Assouad dimension," Journal of Fractal Geometry, vol. 8, no. 4, pp. 363–388, 2021. [Online]. Available: https://ems.press/journals/jfg/articles/2831056

Citation: P. Kern and L. Pleschberger, "Parabolic fractal geometry of stable Lévy processes with drift," Journal of Fractal Geometry, vol. 11, no. 3/4, pp. 343–371, 2024. [Online]. Available: https://ems.press/journals/jfg/articles/14297999
Summary: The paper explicitly calculates the Hausdorff dimension of the graph and range of an isotropic stable Levy process $X$ augmented by a deterministic drift function $f$, employing a restricted variant known as the parabolic Hausdorff dimension. Citation: M. L. Lapidus, G. Radunović, and D. Summary: This paper develops explicit pointwise and distributional fractal tube formulas for a broad class of relative fractal drums (RFDs), defined as pairs $(A, \Omega)$ of subsets in Euclidean spaces of any dimension, thus generalizing the framework from 1D fractal strings to arbitrary dimensions. The central result expresses the volume of the $t$-neighborhood of $A$ intersected with $\Omega$ as a sum of residues over the complex dimensionsi.e., the polesof the meromorphically continued fractal zeta function associated to $(A, \Omega)$ (either distance or tube zeta function). The complex dimensions encapsulate the oscillatory nature and geometric nuances of various fractal examples, including the Sierpinski gasket, 3D fractal carpets, fractal nests, geometric chirps, self-similar sprays, and the Cantor graph (devil's staircase). The work also proposes a new definition of fractality in terms of nonreal complex dimensions or the presence of a natural boundary in the zeta function, emphasizing cases like the subcritically fractal Cantor graph. This unifying approach allows oscillatory geometric features (such as Minkowski measurability and dimensionality) of highly irregular sets to be analyzed via the singularities of the associated zeta functions, subsuming earlier results and opening pathways for further development in higher-dimensional fractal geometry, spectral theory, and mathematical physics.

Citation: Á. G. López, "Dynamics in Fractal Spaces," Fractals, vol. 29, no. 01, pp. 2150016, 2021. [Online]. Available: https://www.worldscientific.com/doi/10.1142/S0218348X2150016X
Summary: We study the dynamics of a particle in a space that is non-differentiable. Non-smooth geometrical objects have an inherently probabilistic nature and, consequently, introduce stochasticity in the motion of a body that lives in their realm. We use the mathematical concept of fiber bundle to characterize the multivalued nature of geodesic trajectories going through a point that is non-differentiable. Then, we generalize our concepts to everywhere non-smooth structures. The resulting theoretical framework can be considered a hybridization of the theory of surfaces and the theory of stochastic processes. We keep the concepts as general as possible, in order to allow for the introduction of other fundamental processes capable of modeling the fractality or the fluctuations of any conceivable continuous, but non-differentiable space.

Citation: G. Calcagni, "Multifractional Theories: An Updated Review," Modern Physics Letters A, vol. 36, no. 04n05, pp. 2130006, 2021. [Online]. Available: https://www.worldscientific.com/doi/abs/10.1142/S021773232140006X
Summary: This review surveys multifractional theories as frameworks for extending classical spacetime geometry by modifying the measure and introducing scale-dependent structures, thus accommodating the possibility of spacetime dimensional flowan idea relevant to quantum gravity. The paper defines the general mathematical structure (including use of nontrivial measures, distinct derivative choices, and altered symmetries), and presents comparative tables (e.g., Table 1) highlighting differences between models based on q-derivatives, weighted derivatives, fractional derivatives, and Caputo derivatives. It provides detailed summaries for the actions, propagators, and spectral dimensions of key models (see Table 2), with unitarity issues noted primarily for Caputo-type fractional derivatives. Multifractional frameworks are examined in the context of ordinary matter, gravitation, cosmological scenarios, and are mapped onto quantum gravity proposals including asymptotic safety, noncommutative geometry, causal sets, loop quantum gravity, and string theory, with extensive comparative tables summarizing these relationships. Key open questions include the interpretation and observability of fractional coordinates, the fate of Lorentz and Poincare invariance, technical and physical ambiguities in the treatment of fractional spacetimes, and connecting theoretical predictions with experiments in cosmology and particle physics. The conclusion emphasizes that multifractional models, though facing mathematical and interpretational challenges, provide a flexible landscape for testing spacetime dimensionality at various scales; the field is sufficiently advanced for detailed confrontation with data and for embedding multifractional geometry within the broader patchwork of quantum gravity.

Citation: K. Ullah and S. K. Katiyar, "Generalized G-Hausdorff space and applications in fractals," Chaos, Solitons & Fractals, vol. 174, 113819, Sep. 2023. [Online]. Available: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0960077923007208

Summary: In this manuscript, the authors extend the classical HutchinsonBarnsley theory to product neutrosophic fractal spaces using iterated function systems characterized by neutrosophic Edelstein contractions alongside finitely many neutrosophic b-contractions. Citation: R. Anttila and S. Eriksson-Bique, "On Constructions of Fractal Spaces Using Replacement and the Combinatorial Loewner Property," arXiv preprint arXiv:2406.08062 [math.MG], 2024. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.08062
Summary: This paper disproves Kleiner's conjecture, which posited that approximately self-similar combinatorially Loewner spaces are quasisymmetric to Loewner spaces, by constructing explicit counterexamples using a novel technique called iterated graph systems (IGS). The authors define and analyze key concepts such as conformal dimension, Ahlfors regularity, modulus (both continuous and combinatorial), and the combinatorial Loewner property (CLP), showing through rigorous modulus and porosity arguments that their IGS-based fractal constructions are self-similar, combinatorially Loewner, but not quasisymmetric to any analytic Loewner space. The main theorem provides simple sufficient conditions for IGS-generated limits to satisfy the CLP, and detailed modulus computations are used to verify both Ahlfors regularity ($Q$-regularity) and the inability for these spaces to attain their conformal dimension. The explicit construction involves removing a removable edge in an IGS, leading to a porous subset and achieving a strict inequality between the Assouad and conformal dimensions. This method generalizes examples (such as the Laakso spaces and their variants) and yields tractable, richer classes of fractals where explicit computation of energies and minimal potentials is possible, often homeomorphic to the Menger curve but far from carpet-like spaces. The constructed examples open a new class of combinatorially Loewner spaces outside the quasisymmetric image of classical Loewner spaces, impacting analysis on fractals, geometric group theory, and the study of modulus and conformal dimension. The work sets a foundation for future research into the attainability of conformal dimensions, analytic properties of broader fractal classes, and in-depth analysis of energy forms and $p$-walk dimensions in these new spaces.

Citation: E. Megias, A. K. Golmankhaneh, and A. Deppman, "Dynamics in fractal spaces," Physics Letters B, vol. 848, p. 138370, 2024. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13627
Summary: This study explores the relationship between the traditional Fokker-Planck Equation (FPE) and its fractal generalization (FFPE) through the use of fractal derivatives, deriving the Plastino-Plastino Equation (PPE) often associated with Tsallis Statistics from a continuous approximation of fractal derivatives in the FPE. The work identifies connections between the entropic index and geometric quantities such as the fractal dimension, analyzing the impact of these relationships on the dynamics of systems within fractal spaces. Numerical comparisons are performed, focusing on the behavior of quark-gluon plasma (QGP), and demonstrate that the FFPE captures distinct dynamics due to the fractal structure of the momentum space, differing from the classic FPE. The results reveal that both the fractal and continuously approximated equations can provide similar insights into system dynamics, permitting their interchangeable use depending on the specific application.

Citation: R. Anttila, S. Eriksson-Bique, and R. Shimizu, "Construction of self-similar energy forms and singularity of Sobolev spaces on Laakso-type fractal spaces," arXiv preprint arXiv:2503.13258 [math.MG], 2025. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2503.13258
Summary: The paper introduces a framework for constructing self-similar $p$-energy forms as normalized limits of discretized $p$-energies on a broad class of Laakso-type fractal spaces termed IGS-fractals (edge-iterated graph systems). Building on the analytic richness of Laakso spaces, the authors propose IGS-fractals as versatile "toy models" for exploring phenomena not otherwise tractable on conventional fractals. Central to their contribution is the discovery of a singularity in Sobolev spaces, where the intrinsic Sobolev spaces $\mathscr{F}_{p_1}$ and $\mathscr{F}_{p_2}$ for distinct exponents $p_1, p_2 \in (1, \infty)$ intersect only at constant functions. This phenomenon is explicitly demonstrated for the Laakso diamond space and analogous IGS-fractals, providing the first self-similar fractal instance with this universal intersection property across exponents. The methods rely on constructing Dirichlet forms through graph approximations and taking normalized limits, with careful combinatorial analysis ensuring convergence and self-similarity. The results delineate the geometry of limit energies, profile the singularity phenomenon, and relate energy measures to geometric invariants like the capacity dimension. The discussion highlights the limitations of classical intuition in these highly singular metric spaces and suggests the framework's utility for future studies in analysis, probability, and geometric group theory, with open directions for non-symmetric energies and stochastic processes.

Citation: I. Biswas, M. Fernández, V. Muñoz, and M. A. Bastón, "On formality of Sasakian manifolds," Journal of Topology, vol. 9, no. 1, pp. 161-180, 2016. [Online]. Available: https://academic.oup.com/jtopol/article/9/1/161/2459653
Summary: We investigate several topological properties of compact Sasakian manifolds, focusing particularly on their formality. Addressing questions posed by Boyer and Galicki, we prove that all higher Massey products (beyond triple) vanish for any compact Sasakian manifold, implying that higher Massey products can indeed act as obstructions to the existence of Sasakian structures. Leveraging this result, we introduce a method to construct simply connected K-contact manifolds that are not Sasakian. Conversely, for every $n \geq 3$, we provide the first examples of simply connected compact Sasakian manifolds of dimension $2n + 1$ that are non-formal, shown by the existence of a non-zero triple Massey product. Additionally, we prove that arithmetic lattices in certain simple Lie groups cannot serve as the fundamental group of any compact Sasakian manifold.

Citation: V. Valov, "Homology manifolds and homogeneous compacta," arXiv preprint arXiv:2505.07196 [math.GN], 2025. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2505.07196
Summary: A non-trivial separable metric space $X$ is called an almost homology $n$-manifold if the homology groups $H_k(X, X\backslash\{x\}, \mathbb{Z})$ are trivial for all $x \in X$ and for all $k = 0, 1, \ldots, n-1$. This work provides a necessary and sufficient condition for locally compact homogeneous $ANR$-spaces or strongly locally homogeneous $ANR$-spaces to be almost homology $n$-manifolds.

Citation: Xin Li, "Ample groupoids, topological full groups, algebraic K-theory spectra and infinite loop spaces," Forum of Mathematics, Pi, vol. 13, 2025, e9. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1017/fmp.2024.31
Summary: Inspired by work of Szymik and Wahl on the homology of HigmanThompson groups, this paper establishes a general connection between ample groupoids, topological full groups, algebraic K-theory spectra, and infinite loop spaces, utilizing the construction of small permutative categories of compact open bisections. This framework enables the analysis of homological invariants of topological full groups in terms of groupoid homology and yields a number of significant results: identification of the (reduced) stable homology of K-theory spectra of bisections with groupoid homology; identification of group homology of topological full groups with that of the infinite loop space associated to the groupoid; complete rational computations for large classes of topological full groups; new general vanishing and acyclicity theorems (e.g., Brin's groups $nV$ are integrally acyclic, and BrinHigmanThompson groups $nV_{k,r}$ are rationally acyclic); the proof of Matuis AH-conjecture for all minimal, ample groupoids with comparison; and the construction of continuum many pairwise nonisomorphic simple integrally acyclic groups. Methodologically, the work develops detailed algebraic, categorical, topological, and homological constructionsincluding new Morita invariance results and tools for computation applicable to broad classes of groupoids, beyond previous limitations. The paper discusses the technical challenges faced, such as constructing permutative categories for general (possibly non-Hausdorff) ample groupoids and establishing comparison properties; it closes by highlighting the applications and future work, including more explicit computations, exploring analytic properties, and investigating when equalities between various subgroups of topological full groups hold. This broad homological toolkit thus opens new avenues for concrete computation, vanishing results, and dynamical and group-theoretic exploration, supported by ERC funding and with no competing interests declared.

Citation: Yoshiko Ogata, "An $H^{3}(G,\mathbb{T})$-valued index of symmetry-protected topological phases with on-site finite group symmetry for two-dimensional quantum spin systems," Forum of Mathematics, Pi, vol. 9, 2021, e13. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1017/fmp.2021.17
Summary: This paper rigorously proves that symmetry-protected topological (SPT) phases in two-dimensional quantum spin systems with on-site finite group symmetry $G$ are classified by an $H^3(G, \mathbb{T})$-valued invariant, confirming a conjecture motivated by tensor network and field theory analyses. Employing operator algebraic techniques, the authors define SPT phases as equivalence classes of gapped Hamiltonians with unique ground states, up to smooth deformation preserving the symmetry and spectral gap, and construct the invariants using a series of detailed algebraic constructions on $\mathbb{Z}^2$ spin lattices. The main result demonstrates that the classification is robust under automorphismsequivalent to finite-depth quantum circuitsmatching physical intuition about short-range entanglement, and ensures that the invariant is stable and independent of construction choices. Consequently, the $H^3(G, \mathbb{T})$-valued index provides a complete and mathematically sound invariant for two-dimensional SPT phases, extending prior results from one dimension, and laying groundwork for further extensions to fermionic systems and higher dimensions.

Summary: Two ring polymers in close proximity can exist in either a segregated phase, characterized by strong monomer repulsion, or a mixed phase, dominated by monomer attraction, with a critical -point demarcating the transition between these phases. The study employs a cubic lattice model of two interacting polygons to analyze the thermodynamic behavior and probability of linking in both phases. It is found that the likelihood of linking is low in the segregated phase but rises as the system transitions through the critical point into the mixed phase. The research also investigates the relationship between averaged topological complexity and the systems metric and thermodynamic properties, showing that these characteristics may change sharply at the phase transition.

Citation: Nick Bultinck, Dominic J Williamson, Jutho Haegeman, and Frank Verstraete, "Fermionic projected entangled-pair states and topological phases," Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical, vol. 51, no. 2, Article 025202, Jan. 2018. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1088/1751-8121/aa99cc
Summary: We study fermionic matrix product operator algebras and identify the associated algebraic data. Using this algebraic data we construct fermionic tensor network states in two dimensions that have non-trivial symmetry-protected or intrinsic topological order. The tensor network states allow us to relate physical properties of the topological phases to the underlying algebraic data. We illustrate this by calculating defect properties and modular matrices of supercohomology phases. Our formalism also captures Majorana defects as we show explicitly for a class of $\mathbb{Z}_2$ symmetry-protected and intrinsic topological phases. The tensor networks states presented here are well-suited for numerical applications and hence open up new possibilities for studying interacting fermionic topological phases.

Citation: Chris Bourne and Emil Prodan, "Non-commutative Chern numbers for generic aperiodic discrete systems," Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical, vol. 51, no. 23, Article 235202, May 2018. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1088/1751-8121/aac093
Summary: The paper introduces the concept of patterned resonators as a unifying theoretical framework for describing topological phases in electronic, photonic, phononic, and other aperiodic systems. It explains the physical intuition behind employing operator-theoretic techniques to analyze these systems and presents a numerical calculation demonstrating quantization of Hall conductance in a 2D amorphous lattice within the mobility gap. The main result extends Chern number formulas to Hamiltonians on lattices lacking a canonical site labeling, and proves index theorems guaranteeing quantization and stability of these Chern numbers under mobility gaps. The framework applies broadly, encompassing quasi-crystalline, amorphous, and algorithmically generated synthetic lattices.

Citation: Julian Legendre, Eduárd Zsurka, Daniele Di Miceli, Llorenç Serra, Kristof Moors, and Thomas L. Schmidt, "Topological properties of finite-size heterostructures of magnetic topological insulators and superconductors," Physical Review B, vol. 110, no. 7, pp. 075426, 2024. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2404.16520 and https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.110.075426
Summary: Heterostructures of magnetic topological insulators (MTIs) and superconductors (SCs) in two-dimensional (2D) slab and one-dimensional (1D) nanoribbon geometries are predicted to host chiral Majorana edge states (CMESs) and Majorana bound states (MBSs), respectively. This study constructs effective symmetry-constrained low-energy Hamiltonians for these systems, incorporating real-space confinement effects, and systematically analyzes their topological properties as a function of chemical potential ($\mu$), magnetic doping ($\lambda$), and proximity-induced superconducting pairing potentials ($\Delta_1,\ \Delta_2$), for both slab and finite-width/length nanoribbon geometries. For slabs, strong magnetic doping induces transitions between trivial, quantum spin Hall (QSH), and quantum anomalous Hall (QAH) phases, while for nanoribbons, a critical width $W_c$ separates regimes of edge-state hybridization and robust chiral edge modes. Bogoliubov-de Gennes (BdG) models reveal rich phase diagrams featuring CMES, MBS, or both, with topological transitions signaled by bulk gap closings and characterized via topological invariants and winding numbers. The interplay between magnetic doping, geometric confinement, and induced superconductivity enables a variety of phasesincluding coexistence of CMESs and MBSsthat may be accessible with current Bi$_2$Se$_3$-based MTI/SC fabrication capabilities. Challenges include addressing disorder, interface sharpness, and the effect of finite temperature and interactions not captured by mean-field theory. Future directions involve considering disorder, complex interface models, nonequilibrium effects, and connections to device architectures for topological quantum computation.

Citation: Guliuxin Jin, D. O. Oriekhov, Lukas Johannes Splitthoff, and Eliska Greplova, "Topological finite size effect in one-dimensional chiral symmetric systems," arXiv preprint arXiv:2411.17822, 2024. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2411.17822 and https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2411.17822
Summary: This paper examines the transition from idealized models of topological phases of matter to finite, real-world systems, focusing on one-dimensional chiral models such as the SSH model. The authors introduce a new criterion for characterizing finite topological systems using bulk conductivity of edge modes, complementing the real-space winding number (RSWN), which can be unreliable in small samples or near phase transitions. Analytical and numerical studies demonstrate that while RSWN deviates for small systems, it converges to k-space predictions with increasing size. Bulk conductivity phase diagramscomputed via the RSWN formulaoffer experimentally accessible means to determine topological phases, remaining robust under symmetry-respecting disorder, and even benefiting from certain chemical potential disorder that breaks chiral symmetry by shifting phase transition points toward ideal values. The combined approach of RSWN and bulk conductivity provides a robust framework for topology identification in intermediate-scale experiments using platforms like synthetic Rydberg atom arrays and quantum dots. Future work will extend these findings to higher-dimensional systems and further benchmarking of experimental topology. Overall, the study supports bulk conductivity as essential for accurately characterizing topology in realistic systems, contributing to both material design and understanding of topological physics.

Citation: Rubén Ballester, Ernst Röell, Daniel Bīn Schmid, Mathieu Alain, Sergio Escalera, Carles Casacuberta, and Bastian Rieck, "MANTRA: The Manifold Triangulations Assemblage," in Proceedings of the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR), 2025. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.02392 and https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2410.02392
Summary: The paper introduces MANTRA, a large-scale, diverse dataset of over 43,000 surface and 250,000 three-dimensional manifold triangulations, designed to fill the gap of intrinsically higher-order datasets for benchmarking topological deep learning (TDL) models, particularly those leveraging simplicial complexes. The authors benchmark twelve state-of-the-art simplicial complex- and graph-based architectures on tasks such as Betti number prediction, homeomorphism type classification, and orientability detection, finding that simplicial complex-based neural networks generally outperform graph-based ones for extracting topological invariants, with performance metrics such as AUROC reaching up to 0.93 for Betti number prediction. However, none of the current modelsincluding higher-order MP and transformer architecturesshow adequate invariance to topological transformations (e.g., barycentric subdivisions), resulting in significant performance drops and near-random outcomes on challenging tasks like orientability prediction. These results highlight key challenges for TDL: the scarcity of suitable benchmarking datasets, suboptimal model invariance, computational bottlenecks, and unsatisfactory results on key tasks. The paper calls for new models capable of leveraging higher-order structure and true topological invariance, suggests enhancing the dataset with more complex and geometric information, and positions MANTRA as a critical benchmark for advancing higher-order and topological machine learning.

Citation: M. W. Ahn, "On the error-sum function of Pierce expansions," Journal of Fractal Geometry, vol. 10, no. 3/4, pp. 389–421, 2023. [Online]. Available: https://ems.press/journals/jfg/articles/12544243
Summary: This paper introduces and investigates the error-sum function for Pierce expansions, extending concepts originally studied for continued fractions. The Pierce expansion is formally defined with an analysis of its digit maps, fundamental intervals, and symbolic space, leading to unique expansions for real numbers in $(0,1)$. The error-sum function is shown to be bounded and continuous almost everywhere, with discontinuities precisely at rational points, and is not of bounded variation. The intermediate value property holds with careful exceptions at discontinuities. Fractal properties of its graph are rigorously examined: the Hausdorff and box-counting dimensions are both found to be $1$, while the covering dimension is $0$, confirming a strictly fractal character. The results highlight both similarities and differences between the error-sum function for Pierce expansions and those for other number-theoretical series. Analytical challenges involve treating discontinuities, symbolic dynamic spaces, and nuanced measure-theoretic properties, while directions for future work include generalizations to more complex representation systems and study of finer statistical aspects.

Citation: L. Jiang and H.-J. Ruan, "Box dimension of generalized affine fractal interpolation functions," Journal of Fractal Geometry, vol. 10, no. 3/4, pp. 279–302, 2023. [Online]. Available: https://ems.press/journals/jfg/articles/11973446
Summary: This paper investigates the box (Minkowski) dimension of the graph $\Gamma_f$ of a generalized affine fractal interpolation function $f$ with a Lipschitz vertical scaling function $S$. By employing vertical scaling matrices that are constructed using $S$ evaluated at partition points and analyzing their spectral radii, the authors derive upper and lower bounds for the oscillation of $f$, leading to an explicit formula for $\dim_B \Gamma_f$ under certain structural matrix conditions. The methodology generalizes classical results for constant or linear $S$, demonstrating that the geometric complexity of the graph is intrinsically linked to the spectral properties of associated matrices. A concrete example with partition $N=3$ and a step function $S(x)$ illustrates the computation. The results are sharp when the spectral radius condition (greater than one) is satisfied; however, degenerate cases require more elaborate analysis. The work sets the stage for future exploration of less regular scaling functions, randomization, and extensions to higher dimensions and more general partition structures. The key equation for the box-counting dimension is $\dim_B K = \lim_{\varepsilon \to 0^+} \frac{\log N(K,\varepsilon)}{\log(1/\varepsilon)}$, and the explicit box dimension formula in terms of the spectral radius is derived under suitable hypotheses.

Citation: S.-M. Ngai and W. Tang, "Schrödinger equations defined by a class of self-similar measures," Journal of Fractal Geometry, vol. 10, no. 3/4, pp. 209–241, 2023. [Online]. Available: https://ems.press/journals/jfg/articles/11973445
Summary: We study linear and non-linear Schrodinger equations defined by fractal measures. Under the assumption that the Laplacian has compact resolvent, we prove that there exists a unique weak solution for a linear Schrodinger equation, and then use it to obtain the existence and uniqueness of a weak solution of a non-linear Schrodinger equation. We prove that for a class of self-similar measures on $\mathbb{R}$ with overlaps, the linear Schrodinger equations can be discretized so that the finite element method can be applied to obtain approximate solutions. We also prove that the numerical solutions converge to the actual solution and obtain the rate of convergence.

Citation: M. S. Hussein, "A survey on the computational methods for the determination of fractal dimensions and types of fractals," Fractals, vol. 28, no. 7, pp. 2040033-1–2040033-22, 2020. [Online]. Available: https://www.worldscientific.com/doi/abs/10.1142/S0218348X20400338
Summary: Fractals are irregular geometric objects characterized by self-similarity, meaning their overall shapes are reflected at every scale. They have widespread applications in science and engineering, necessitating the determination of fractal dimensions to quantify their degree of irregularity or fragmentation. This paper surveys a broad range of computational methods for estimating fractal dimensions and classifies different fractal types by their geometrical properties. It discusses various approaches for fractal dimension calculation, detailing their advantages, disadvantages, and implementation aspects, to enhance understanding of their computational properties.

Citation: C. Bandt and D. Mekhontsev, "Elementary Fractal Geometry. 2. Carpets Involving Irrational Rotations," Fractal and Fractional, vol. 6, no. 1, p. 39, 2022. [Online]. Available: https://www.mdpi.com/2504-3110/6/1/39
Summary: Self-similar sets satisfying the open set condition, commonly studied as linear fractal geometric objects, have predominantly focused on crystallographic frameworks; however, this work introduces novel symmetry classes in the plane structured around rotations by irrational angles. Through a computer-assisted search, the authors found examples that exhibit no characteristic directions, strong connectedness, and low complexity, which is notable because the associated rotations are given by rational matriceswhile proofs for the open set condition typically require integer coefficients. The paper develops a classification of such self-similar sets according to symmetry class and algebraic numbers, providing explicit examples for various quadratic number fields.

Citation: S.I. Ri, V. Drakopoulos, and S.M. Nam, "Fractal Interpolation Using Harmonic Functions on the Koch Curve," Fractal and Fractional, vol. 5, no. 2, p. 28, 2021. [Online]. Available: https://www.mdpi.com/2504-3110/5/2/28
Summary: An in-depth discussion on the theory of affine fractal interpolation functions generating the Koch Curve by using fractal analysis as well as its recent developments is presented. The construction of harmonic functions on the Koch Curve is investigated and the existence and uniqueness of corresponding fractal interpolation functions are proved.

Citation: Md. N. Akhtar, M.G.P. Prasad, M.A. Navascués, and R.N. Mohapatra, "Fractal Dimension of Fractal Functions on the Real Projective Plane," Fractal and Fractional, vol. 7, no. 7, p. 510, 2023. [Online]. Available: https://www.mdpi.com/2504-3110/7/7/510
Summary: This paper extends the classical theory of fractal interpolation and fractal functions from the Euclidean setting to the non-Euclidean real projective plane. By defining a linear structure on an interval of the projective plane and considering iterated function systems (IFS) composed of affine projective contractions, the authors construct fractal graphs as attractors of such systemsthese are continuous functions exhibiting rich topological and geometric properties. Explicitly, if the IFS consists of $d$ contractions with ratios $r_1,\ldots,r_d$, then the box-counting, packing, and Hausdorff dimensions of the fractal graph all coincide and are determined as the unique solution $s > 0$ to the Moran-type equation $\sum_{i=1}^d r_i^s = 1$. The attractors possess topological dimension one but can exhibit fractal dimensions strictly greater than one and arbitrarily close to two as contraction ratios increase, thus producing highly irregular "wild" functions. The work recovers the classical Euclidean results as a limiting case and illustrates both theoretical advancements and computational challenges in adapting separation conditions and visualizations to the projective context. The article concludes by suggesting extensions to higher-dimensional projective spaces and further studies on the analytic properties of these fractal functions.

Citation: A. Berdnikov, L. Guth, and F. Manin, "Degrees of maps and multiscale geometry," Forum of Mathematics, Pi, vol. 12, 2024, e2. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1017/fmp.2023.33
Summary: This paper investigates the relationship between the Lipschitz constant $L$ of self-maps on Riemannian manifolds and the maximal degree such maps can achieve, focusing on upper bounds, constructions, and classifying behaviors based on manifold topology. For the connected sum $X_k = \#_k \mathbb{CP}^2$ with $k \geq 4$, the authors show the maximum degree of an $L$-Lipschitz self-map lies between $C_1 L^4 (\log L)^{-4}$ and $C_2 L^4 (\log L)^{-1/2}$, for explicit constants $C_1$ and $C_2$. The study introduces a topological trichotomy: (1) scalable, simply connected $n$-manifolds achieve the optimal scaling $\sim L^n$; (2) formal but nonscalable ones have degree growth bounded by $L^n (\log L)^{-\theta(1)}$; (3) nonformal manifolds have maximal degree $L^\alpha$ for some $\alpha < n$. Methods employ Fourier analysis and LittlewoodPaley theory to analyze forms and cohomology classes, as well as constructive gluing and combinatorial methods for mapping construction. A sharp phase transition is demonstrated between these topological types, with comprehensive bounds and explicit criteria for scalability derived from algebraic properties such as the structure of the real cohomology ring. The discussion highlights the interplay between topology, analysis, and algebra, and acknowledges challenges in fully characterizing nonformal manifolds. The work lays a foundation for future studies aiming to further refine quantitative bounds and understand the rational invariance of the observed mapping degree behaviors.

Citation: J. Miller, S. Sheffield, and W. Werner, "CLE Percolations," Forum of Mathematics, Pi, vol. 5, 2017, e4. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1017/fmp.2017.5
Summary: Conformal loop ensembles (CLEs) are random, conformally invariant collections of loops in a simply connected domain, with the set of points not surrounded by any CLE loop providing a continuum analogue of the Sierpinski gasket or carpet. This work establishes a direct relationship between each CLE consisting of simple disjoint loops (CLE$(\kappa)$ for $\kappa \in (8/3, 4)$) and the associated CLE$(\kappa')$, where $\kappa' = 16/\kappa$, which involves generally non-disjoint loopsmirroring the Edwards-Sokal coupling between the $q$-state Potts and the FK random cluster models, generalized to non-integer $q$. The correspondence operates bidirectionally: (1) one can sample a CLE$(\kappa')$, randomly color each loop, and form CLE$(\kappa)$ from cluster outer boundaries of a chosen color; and (2) CLE$(\kappa')$ loops can be interpreted as interfaces of a continuum percolation model within a CLE$(\kappa)$ carpet. This yields the first construction of continuous percolation interfaces in fractal domains and elucidates connections between CLEs and the Gaussian free field. The work also contributes results on generalized SLE$(\kappa;\rho)$ curves and introduces boundary conformal loop ensembles (BCLEs), a continuum of natural CLE variants sharing some conformal symmetries; the developed correspondence extends to BCLEs for all $\kappa \in [2,4]$, suggesting scaling limits for critical models with certain boundary conditions.

Citation: A. Hammond, "A patchwork quilt sewn from Brownian fabric: Regularity of polymer weight profiles in Brownian last passage percolation," Forum of Mathematics, Pi, vol. 7, 2019, e2. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1017/fmp.2019.2
Summary: In the KardarParisiZhang (KPZ) universality class for last passage percolation models, the energy of long, energy-maximizing paths, known as polymers, can be studied as a function of their endpoint locations, with scaling introduced so that these paths and their energies exhibit unit-order fluctuations and weights. Focusing on Brownian last passage percolation under these scaled coordinates, in the narrow wedge scenariowhere a polymer's origin is fixed at $(0,0)$ and its endpoint varies horizontally at $(z,1)$the profile of polymer weights as a function of $z$ is locally Brownian. Prior results showed that, after suitable affine adjustment, the law governing this profile is closely comparable to Brownian bridge, with the RadonNikodym derivative lying in every $L^p$ space for $p\in (1,\infty)$, uniformly in scale. This work generalizes the analysis to polymers with general initial conditions, proving that on a compact interval, the profile, split into a random yet well-controlled number of affine-adjusted patches, resembles a Brownian bridge locally such that the RadonNikodym derivative belongs to every $L^p$ space for $p \in (1,3)$. This result leverages recent advances in describing the uniform coalescence structure within the polymer field and makes use of techniques from prior foundational works.

Citation: Biplab Pal, “A fractal geometry immersed in a hierarchical magnetic flux distribution,” Journal of Applied Physics, vol. 137, no. 14, p. 144301, 2025. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.12972
Summary: Fractal geometry, characterized by self-similarity across scales, is modeled here via a Sierpinski gasket (SPG) lattice subjected to a deterministic hierarchical distribution of magnetic flux, introducing a controlled disorder to the Aharonov-Bohm (AB) phases ($\phi$) experienced by electrons. Employing tight-binding formalism, the study demonstrates that the hierarchical parameter governing these AB phases can systematically manipulate quantum states and persistent currents within the SPG fractal lattice. Importantly, tuning this parameter enables regulation of persistent current across various electronic filling factors, suggesting potential applications in designing nanoelectronic devices built from chemically synthesized molecular fractal structures.

Citation: Lulu Fang, Carlos Gustavo Moreira, and Yiwei Zhang, “Fractal geometry of continued fractions with large coefficients and dimension drop problems,” arXiv preprint arXiv:2409.00521, 2024. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2409.00521
Summary: This paper presents a comprehensive study of the Hausdorff dimension of sets of real numbers whose continued fraction coefficients exhibit various growth behaviors. Building upon foundational work by Jarnik (who showed that bounded partial quotients lead to dimension one) and Good (who discovered a "dimension drop" to $1/2$ for coefficients tending to infinity), the authors generalize and unify much of the existing dimension-drop literature. They characterize the Hausdorff dimension of such sets in terms of thermodynamic pressure equations, employing methods such as mass distribution principles, construction of Cantor-type sets, and multifractal analysis. The main theorem offers a precise formula linking dimension to growth rates, thereby explaining the transition of dimension from $1$ to $1/2$ and further towards $0$ as constraints on the coefficients become stricter. Applications include new proofs for the dimension of Borel-Bernstein sets, a complete resolution of dimension gaps from Liao and Rams, and sharp results for liminf/limsup sets concerning the maximum partial quotient. The work also discusses the sensitivity of these dimensions to many parameter choices, explores implications for Fractal Geometry and Diophantine approximation, and outlines open problems and future directions such as multifractal spectra for irregular growth and connections to dynamical systems. Overall, the authors provide an essentially complete solution to a significant open problem in fractal and number theory, captured by the following dimension formula: for the set $E(\varphi) = \{x : a_n(x) \geq \varphi(n)\,\, \text{for all large}\,\, n\}$, the Hausdorff dimension $\dim_H(E(\varphi))$ is determined as the unique $s$ satisfying the pressure equation $P(s, \varphi) = 0$, where $P$ involves the growth rate of $\varphi$ and the statistical properties of continued fractions.

Citation: Julia El Zini, Bassel Musharrafieh, and Mariette Awad, “On The Potential of The Fractal Geometry and The CNNs Ability to Encode it,” arXiv preprint arXiv:2401.04141, 2024. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.04141
Summary: The fractal dimension provides a statistical index of object complexity by studying how the pattern changes with the measuring scale. Although useful in several classification tasks, the fractal dimension is under-explored in deep learning applications. In this work, we investigate the features that are learned by deep models and we study whether these deep networks are able to encode features as complex and high-level as the fractal dimensions. Specifically, we conduct a correlation analysis experiment to show that deep networks are not able to extract such a feature in none of their layers. We combine our analytical study with a human evaluation to investigate the differences between deep learning networks and models that operate on the fractal feature solely. Moreover, we show the effectiveness of fractal features in applications where the object structure is crucial for the classification task. We empirically show that training a shallow network on fractal features achieves performance comparable, even superior in specific cases, to that of deep networks trained on raw data while requiring less computational resources. Fractals improved the accuracy of the classification by 30% on average while requiring up to 84% less time to train. We couple our empirical study with a complexity analysis of the computational cost of extracting the proposed fractal features, and we study its limitation.

Citation: M. T. Barlow and M. Murugan, "Stability of the elliptic Harnack inequality," Annals of Mathematics, vol. 187, no. 3, pp. 777–823, 2018. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.4007/annals.2018.187.3.4
Summary: This paper proves that the elliptic Harnack inequality (EHI), a fundamental analytic property relevant for harmonic functions on weighted graphs, Riemannian manifolds, and metric measure spaces, is stable under both bounded perturbations of the underlying structure and under rough (or quasi-) isometries between spaces. Using heat kernel methods, coupling arguments, and potential theoryparticularly involving Dirichlet forms, resistance metrics, and capacitythe authors show that if two infinite, connected, locally finite weighted graphs are roughly isometric and one satisfies EHI, then so does the other; similar results hold for manifolds and metric measure spaces. Importantly, their argument removes the need for assuming Poincare or volume doubling properties, extending the applicability of EHI stability far beyond classical scenarios. The methods are robust to irregularities and do not require strong global regularity or established heat kernel bounds, clarifying the geometric and analytic features that dictate when the EHI holds. This establishes that the class of spaces supporting the EHI forms a stable equivalence class under bounded perturbations and rough isometries, with implications for potential theory and geometric analysis, and opens the way for further generalizations, including parabolic and boundary Harnack inequalities.

Citation: R. H. Bamler, "Convergence of Ricci flows with bounded scalar curvature," Annals of Mathematics, vol. 188, no. 3, pp. 753–831, 2018. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.4007/annals.2018.188.3.2
Summary: In this paper we prove convergence and compactness results for Ricci flows with bounded scalar curvature and entropy. More specifically, we show that Ricci flows with bounded scalar curvature converge smoothly away from a singular set of codimension $\geq 4$. We also establish a general form of the Hamilton-Tian Conjecture, which is even true in the Riemannian case. These results are based on a compactness theorem for Ricci flows with bounded scalar curvature, which states that any sequence of such Ricci flows converges, after passing to a subsequence, to a metric space that is smooth away from a set of codimension $\geq 4$. In the course of the proof, we will also establish $L^{p < 2}$-curvature bounds on time-slices of such flows.

Citation: A. Naor, "Discrete Riesz transforms and sharp metric $X_p$ inequalities," Annals of Mathematics, vol. 184, no. 3, pp. 991–1016, 2016. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.4007/annals.2016.184.3.9
Summary:
For $p\in [2,\infty)$, the metric $X_p$ inequality with sharp scaling parameter is proven to hold in $L_p$. This leads to sharp geometric results for embeddings of $L_q$ into $L_p$ when $2< q<p<\infty$: specifically, the maximal $\theta\in (0,1]$ for which $L_q$ allows a bi-$\theta$-Holder embedding into $L_p$ equals $q/p$, and for $m,n\in \mathbb{N}$, the smallest bi-Lipschitz distortion of any embedding into $L_p$ of the grid $\{1,\ldots,m\}^n\subset \ell_q^n$ is bounded above and below (up to constants depending only on $p,q$) by
\[
\min\left\{n^{\frac{(p-q)(q-2)}{q^2(p-2)}},\; m^{(q-2)/q}\right\}.
\]

Citation: David Bate, "Purely unrectifiable metric spaces and perturbations of Lipschitz functions," Acta Mathematica, vol. 224, no. 1, pp. 1–116, 2020. [Online]. Available: https://projecteuclid.org/journals/acta-mathematica/volume-224/issue-1/Purely-unrectifiable-metric-spaces-and-perturbations-of-Lipschitz-functions/10.4310/ACTA.2020.v224.n1.a1.pdf
Summary: We characterise purely $n$-unrectifiable subsets $S$ of a complete metric space $X$ with finite Hausdorff $n$-measure by studying arbitrarily small perturbations of elements of $\operatorname{Lip}_1 (X, m)$, the set of all bounded $1$-Lipschitz functions $f : X \to \mathbb{R}^m$ with respect to the supremum norm. In one such characterisation it is shown that, if $S$ has positive lower density almost everywhere, then the set of all $f$ with $\mathcal{H}^n (f(S)) = 0$ is residual in $\operatorname{Lip}_1 (X, m)$. Conversely, if $E \subset X$ is $n$-rectifiable with $\mathcal{H}^n (E) > 0$, the set of all $f$ with $\mathcal{H}^n (f(E)) > 0$ is residual in $\operatorname{Lip}_1 (X, m)$. These results provide a replacement for the BesicovitchFederer projection theorem in arbitrary metric spaces, which is known to be false outside of Euclidean spaces.

Citation: Christoph Böhm and Ramiro A. Lafuente, "Non-compact Einstein manifolds with symmetry," Journal of the American Mathematical Society, vol. 36, pp. 591–651, 2023. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1090/jams/1022
Summary: This paper establishes a major rigidity result for Einstein manifolds with negative scalar curvature that admit an isometric Lie group action with a compact, smooth orbit space: the nilradical $N$ of the group acts polarly, and $N$-orbits can be extended to minimal Einstein submanifolds. The central achievement is a proof of the Alekseevskii conjecture, confirming that any homogeneous Einstein manifold with negative scalar curvature is diffeomorphic to $\mathbb{R}^n$ (Euclidean space), i.e., topologically trivial, with every such space shown to be a solvmanifold. The Einstein condition is characterized by the Ricci tensor equation $\operatorname{ric}(g) = \lambda g$ for $\lambda < 0$, and the authors employ tools from geometric invariant theory, a modified Helmholtz decomposition for vector fields, divergence formulas, the Bochner technique, and Riemannian submersions (using O'Neill formulas) to analyze the implications of isometric group actions and the structure of orbits. Further results include that any homogeneous expanding Ricci soliton is isometric to a solvsoliton and that any compact, locally homogeneous Einstein manifold with negative scalar curvature must be locally symmetric. The discussion highlights the broad implications for the structure theory of non-compact homogeneous Einstein spaces, emphasizing the role of solvmanifolds, rigidity via polar actions, and the interplay of curvature, symmetry, and topology, with new decompositions and methods applicable to broader geometric analysis.

Citation: Pierre Lairez, "Rigid continuation paths I. Quasilinear average complexity for solving polynomial systems," Journal of the American Mathematical Society, vol. 33, pp. 487–526, 2020. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1090/jams/938
Summary: This paper addresses the computational complexity of finding an approximate root of a random Gaussian polynomial system, providing a quasi-optimal average-case bound of $(\text{input size})^{1+o(1)}$ operations, which significantly improves upon the previous $(\text{input size})^{3/2 + o(1)}$ bound. The authors introduce a randomized algorithm that employs numerical continuation along rigid continuation pathsusing rigid motions of the equations instead of the usual linear pathswhich leads to a lower average condition number and permits larger steps. Methodologically, the core innovations include the split gamma number (a refinement of Smale's classical gamma number) and the restriction of averaging to random rigid motions, yielding superior estimates for the average number of continuation steps. For a system of $n$ homogeneous equations of degree at most $D$, the algorithm requires $O(n^4 D^2)$ continuation steps and $O(n^6 D^4 N)$ total operations, given input size $N$. Analytical results are established under the Kostlan distribution, leveraging its unitary invariance. The discussion highlights the broader implications of the rigid path framework for numerical algebraic geometry, emphasizing both theoretical improvements and potential practical benefits, such as larger steps and lower computational effort. The work overcomes significant challenges in parameter space design and regularity of paths, and introduces techniques for efficient approximation of condition numbers using a Frobenius-norm variant of the gamma number. In conclusion, by reparameterizing continuation paths via rigid motions, the paper refines the quantitative answer to Smales 17th problem and suggests new avenues for both theory and practical algorithms in polynomial system solving.

Citation: Uri Bader, Pierre-Emmanuel Caprace, and Jean Lécureux, "On the linearity of lattices in affine buildings and ergodicity of the singular Cartan flow," Journal of the American Mathematical Society, vol. 32, pp. 491–562, 2019. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1090/jams/914
Summary: Let $X$ be a locally finite irreducible affine building of dimension $\geq 2$ and $\Gamma \leq \mathrm{Aut}(X)$ a discrete group acting cocompactly. This paper investigates when $\Gamma$ is linear, or more broadly, when $\Gamma$ has a finite-dimensional representation with infinite image over a commutative unital ring. While $\Gamma$ is linear for $X$ as the Bruhat--Tits building of a simple algebraic group over a local field and $\Gamma$ an arithmetic lattice, the authors prove the converse for buildings of type $\widetilde A_2$: cocompact lattices in exotic $\widetilde A_2$-buildings are non-linear. They apply this to construct the first infinite family of lattices in exotic $\widetilde A_2$-buildings with arbitrarily large thickness, partially answering a question by W. Kantor (1986). Furthermore, for Bruhat--Tits buildings of any type, they show that if $\Gamma$ is linear, it is virtually contained in the linear part of the automorphism group of $X$, so $\Gamma$ must be arithmetic. The proofs rely on algebraic representations of ergodic systems by Bader and Furman, and crucially involve constructing the ergodic $\Gamma$-space called the singular Cartan flow associated to $X$.

Citation: L. Hitruhin and A. Tsantaris, "Quasiconformal curves and quasiconformal maps in metric spaces," Analysis and Geometry in Metric Spaces, vol. 13, no. 1, pp. 20250019, 2025. [Online]. Available: https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/agms-2025-0019/html
Summary: This article investigates quasiconformal curves, viewed as Sobolev class embeddings $f: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}^m$ ($n \leq m$) from domains $\Omega \subset \mathbb{R}^n$ that satisfy a distortion inequality involving a smooth, closed, non-vanishing $n$-form in $\mathbb{R}^m$. The authors demonstrate that such quasiconformal $\omega$-curves always fulfill the analytic definition of quasiconformal mappings and satisfy the lower bound of the modulus inequality. They further provide sufficient conditions under which these curves adhere to the metric definition of quasiconformality and prove that any quasiconformal map from $\Omega$ to $f(\Omega) \subset \mathbb{R}^m$ is, under suitable assumptions, a quasiconformal $\omega$-curve. The results extend to settings where $f(\Omega)$ is equipped with its intrinsic metric, maintaining the equivalence between analytic and geometric definitions. While key moduli inequalities and analytic characterizations generalize, the equivalence of all quasiconformal definitions often depends on geometric properties like projection finiteness or Ahlfors regularity of the image, and counterexamples show the failure of properties such as upper Ahlfors regularity or local linear connectivity in general. The work provides higher integrability results, explores absolute continuity, and clarifies the limits of quasisymmetry for quasiconformal curves, outlining open questions for further research on the geometric underpinning necessary for full equivalence of definitions.

Citation: D. Cao Labora, F. J. Fernández, F. A. F. Tojo, and C. Villanueva Mariz, "Necessary and sufficient conditions for distances on the real line," Analysis and Geometry in Metric Spaces, vol. 13, no. 1, pp. 20250022, 2025. [Online]. Available: https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/agms-2025-0022/html
Summary: This paper establishes necessary and sufficient analytical criteria for determining when a function $d: \mathbb{R}^2 \rightarrow [0, \infty)$ induces a metric (distance) on the real line, focusing on properties such as positivity, symmetry, and the triangle inequality. The core approach leverages analysis of directional and cross partial derivatives: if $d$ is sufficiently regular and its cross partial derivative is non-negative away from the diagonal, with suitable monotonicity or limiting behavior, then $d$ satisfies the triangle inequality and thus defines a metric. The results provide easy-to-check hypotheses, facilitate handling less regular functions via coordinate transformations (such as order-preserving bijections), and generalize to cover classical and more exotic metrics. Example applications include concave translation-invariant metrics $d(x, y) = g(|y-x|)$ with $g$ concave; $p$-relative metrics $d(x, y) = |y-x| (|x|^p + |y|^p)^{1/p}$ for $p \geq 1$; and generalized chordal metrics $d(x, y) = |y-x| (\alpha + \beta|x|^p)^{1/p} (\alpha + \beta|y|^p)^{1/p}$ for $\alpha > 0$, $\beta \geq 0$, $p \geq 1$. These insights narrow the gap between ad hoc verifications and general metric criteria, making it easier to construct and verify new distances on $\mathbb{R}$.

Citation: Y. Yu, "Blow-ups of minimal surfaces in the Heisenberg group," Analysis and Geometry in Metric Spaces, vol. 13, no. 1, pp. 20250021, 2025. [Online]. Available: https://www.degruyterbrill.com/document/doi/10.1515/agms-2025-0021/html
Summary: This paper revises and corrects Montis results concerning blow-ups of H-perimeter minimizing sets in the Heisenberg group $\mathbb{H}^n$, clarifying the partial differential equation (PDE) satisfied by the limit of rescaled intrinsic Lipschitz approximations. Previous work claimed that the blow-up limit function $\varphi$ (obtained as the weak $L^2$ limit of the normalized approximations) was independent of $y_1$ and solved a harmonic equation involving the KohnLaplacian, but this article demonstrates both claims are incorrect due to a miscalculation in first variation analysis. Instead, for $n \geq 2$, if $E \subset \mathbb{H}^n$ is H-perimeter minimizing near $0$ and $\nu_E(0) = (1,0,\ldots,0)$, the blow-up limit $\varphi$ solves weakly in $D_{1/4}$ the PDE $\frac{\partial}{\partial y_1} \Delta_0 \varphi = 0$, where $\Delta_0 = \frac{\partial^2}{\partial y_1^2} + \sum_{i=2}^n X_i^2 + Y_i^2$; for strongly H-perimeter minimizing sets, the equation simplifies to $\Delta_0 \varphi = 0$. The methodology involves refined blow-up analysis, weak convergence techniques, and corrected first variation computations using contact flows, showing subtle effects of the Heisenberg groups non-commutativity. This correction not only amends the PDE governing the geometric structure of blow-up limits, but also leaves open the challenge of establishing regularity and potential decay lemmas for solutions to this new PDE, offering a clear path for further research in the regularity theory of minimal surfaces in sub-Riemannian geometry.

Citation: Y. Ishiki and K. Koshino, "On isometric universality of spaces of metrics," arXiv preprint arXiv:2409.17701, 18 pages, Sep. 2024. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2409.17701
Summary:
The paper investigates universality properties of metric spaces of the form $(\mathrm{Met}(Z), D_Z)$, where $Z$ is a metrizable space and $D_Z$ is a pointwise metric (typically the supremum distance on the space of metrics over $Z$). It shows that if $Z$ has sufficiently many subspaces, then the space of bounded metrics on $Z$ is universal for all bounded metric spaces with cardinality at most that of $Z$; in particular, for spaces like $l^2(\kappa)$, $Q$ (rationals), and other classical objects, explicit universality results are given, often via operator-theoretic and embedding constructions. For infinite discrete $Z$, the metric space of metrics on $Z$ is universal for all separable metric spaces, and spaces like $\ell^\infty(\kappa)$ are realized as subspaces. However, when $Z$ is compact and countable, universality fails: there exist compact metric spaces that cannot be isometrically embedded into $\mathrm{Met}(Z)$. On the positive side, every compact subset of $c_0(\omega_0)$ embeds isometrically into $\mathrm{Met}(Z)$ for countably infinite $Z$. The analysis connects functional analysis, topology, and set theory, with explicit embedding techniques (using theorems on extension, Banach space embeddings, and transfinite constructions), and raises open problems about universality for unbounded spaces, finite injectivity, and embeddings of the Urysohn space. The paper presents a clear classification of when and how universality occurs, as compactly summarized:

\[
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|}
\hline
\text{Space $Z$} & \text{Universality of $(\mathrm{Met}(Z), D_Z)$} & \text{Classes Universal For} \\
\hline
\text{Abundant subspaces} & \text{Universal} & \text{Bounded metric spaces, $|X| \leq |Z|$} \\
\text{Infinite discrete} & \text{Universal} & \text{Separable metric spaces} \\
\text{Compact, countable} & \text{Not universal} & -- \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\]

The results delineate the boundary between possible and impossible universality for moduli spaces of metrics, and set the stage for further research connecting metric geometry, topology, and functional analysis.

Citation: A. Bykov, E. Minguzzi, and S. Suhr, "Lorentzian metric spaces and GH-convergence: the unbounded case," arXiv preprint arXiv:2412.04311, 69 pages, revised May 2025. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2412.04311
Summary: The paper introduces a general notion of Lorentzian metric space by removing the previously imposed boundedness condition, establishing a minimal set of defining properties: (a) the reverse triangle inequality for chronologically related events, (b) continuity of the Lorentzian distance and relative compactness of chronological diamonds, and (c) a distinguishing condition via the Lorentzian distance function. By augmenting these with a countably generating condition, the authors secure desirable features such as the Polish property. The concept of (pre-)length space is generalized to this unbounded setting, and a new notion of Gromov-Hausdorff (GH) convergence for sequenced Lorentzian spaces is defined, showing that (pre-)length spaces remain GH-stable. The work further proves that such spaces admit canonical quasi-uniform and quasi-metric structures, simplifying results like the limit curve theorem and the analysis of precompactness, and draws explicit comparisons with other frameworks in the literature. The approach paves the way for synthetic treatments of spacetime geometry that extend beyond smooth manifolds, offering potential applications in generalized relativity, quantum gravity, and causet theory.

Citation: D. Martínez and F. Vigolo, "C*-rigidity of bounded geometry metric spaces," arXiv preprint arXiv:2501.03128, 15 pages, Jan. 2025. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2501.03128
Summary:
This paper establishes that for uniformly locally finite metric spaces, isomorphic Roe algebras imply the spaces are coarsely equivalent, resolving a central question in C*-rigidity that bridges operator algebra and coarse geometry. Roe algebras, constructed from large-scale geometric data of metric spaces, serve as operator-algebraic invariants, and the main result proves a complete correspondence: $C^*$-algebra isomorphism of Roe algebras characterizes coarse equivalence of the underlying spaces with bounded geometry. The methods include careful development of mathematical preliminaries, key technical results such as a concentration inequality (Lemma 3.1) and analysis of quasilocality (Proposition 3.2), and construction of coarse equivalences from spatially implemented isomorphisms and unitary elements (Theorems 2.14, 2.15). A further main result identifies the outer automorphism group of the Roe algebra, $\operatorname{Out}(C^*_{\mathrm{Roe}}(X))$, with the group of coarse equivalences of $X$ up to closeness, showing this correspondence is canonical and functorial. The table of correspondences is:

\[
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Roe algebra isomorphisms} & \text{Coarse equivalence} \\
\hline
\text{Outer automorphisms} & \text{Coarse equivalence (modulo closeness)} \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\]

These results generalize prior work, deliver a functorial operator algebra/coarse geometry bridge, and clarify the structure and uniqueness of Roe algebras as coarse invariants.

Citation: I. G. Korepanov, "Self-similarity in cubic blocks of R-operators," Journal of Mathematical Physics, vol. 64, no. 10, pp. 101704-1–101704-33, Oct. 2023. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0143884

Citation: G. Mograby, R. Balu, K. A. Okoudjou, and A. Teplyaev, "Spectral decimation of a self-similar version of almost Mathieu-type operators," Journal of Mathematical Physics, vol. 63, no. 5, pp. 053501-1–053501-23, May 2022. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0078939

Citation: V. E. Adler and M. P. Kolesnikov, "Non-Abelian Toda lattice and analogs of Painlevé III equation," Journal of Mathematical Physics, vol. 63, no. 10, pp. 103504-1–103504-24, Oct. 2022. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0091939

Citation: Engin Özkan, Bahar Kuloǧlu, James F. Peters, "K-NARAYANA SEQUENCE SELF-SIMILARITY," Chaos, Solitons & Fractals, 2021. [Online]. Available: https://hal.science/hal-03242990

Summary: In this article, the random walk (RW) problem is analyzed with a focus on self-similarity, dynamic scaling, and its relation to diffusion phenomena, with particular attention to the effect of various step size choices. Citation: Sérgio Luiz E. F. da Silva, "κ-generalised Gutenberg–Richter law and the self-similarity of earthquakes," Chaos, Solitons & Fractals, vol. 143, Article 110622, February 2021. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chaos.2020.110622
Summary: The statistical analysis of earthquakes is fundamental for understanding regional seismic activity and for seismic hazard assessment. The study finds the entropic index of Kaniadakis entropy is a near-universal parameter (approximately 1) and provides evidence for the fractal, self-similar structure of the tectonic plate fragments and earthquake occurrences, irrespective of magnitude.

Citation: M. Hassanaly and V. Raman, “A self-similarity principle for the computation of rare event probability,” Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical, vol. 52, no. 49, pp. 495501, 2019. doi:10.1088/1751-8121/ab5313. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1088/1751-8121/ab5313

A self-similarity model is developed and validated with both a priori and a posteriori analysis, and further tested on a high-dimensional chaotic system, namely a turbulent combustion problem with $10^7$ degrees of freedom. While strict self-similarity does not universally hold, the model effectively approximates rare mean paths, offering a promising approach for studying rare event statistics in complex systems.

Citation: N. K. Bell, V. N. Grebenev, S. B. Medvedev, and S. V. Citation: R. R. Nigmatullin and Y. Chen, "Self-Similarity Principle and the General Theory of Fractal Elements: How to Fit a Random Curve with a Clearly Expressed Trend?," Mathematics, vol. 11, no. 12, p. 2781, 2023. [Online]. Available: https://www.mdpi.com/2227-7390/11/12/2781

Citation: A. Ryskan, Z. Arzikulov, T. Ergashev, and A. Berdyshev, "Self-Similar Solutions of a Multidimensional Degenerate Partial Differential Equation of the Third Order," Mathematics, vol. 12, no. 20, p. 3188, 2024. [Online]. Available: https://www.mdpi.com/2227-7390/12/20/3188

Citation: N. Bempedelis, L. Magri, and K. Steiros, "Extracting self-similarity from data," arXiv preprint arXiv:2407.10724, 2024. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2407.10724

The authors emphasize opportunities to extend the framework to more complex systems and multi-scale problems and provide open-source code and data to facilitate further application.

Citation: H. Kwon, M. Kim, S. Kwak, and M. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2102.07092
Summary: The paper proposes a novel video motion representation called spatio-temporal self-similarity (STSS), where each region in a sequence of frames is characterized by its similarity to spatial and temporal neighbors. The authors introduce the SELFY neural block, which processes video features $V$ into an STSS tensor $S$, extracts features $F$ from $S$, integrates them into a final representation $Z$, and fuses $Z$ back into $V$ via residual addition. This design allows the capture of both long-term interactions and fast motions without extra supervision. Experiments show that SELFY improves robustness under occlusion and motion blur, is complementary to conventional spatio-temporal convolution features, and delivers state-of-the-art results on benchmarks including Something-Something-V1/V2, Diving-48, and FineGym. Extensive ablation and performance studies reveal the superior motion modeling of STSS, its relation to self-attention mechanisms, and its effective integration into neural architectures.

Citation: K. Ohkitani, "Self-similarity in turbulence and its applications," arXiv preprint arXiv:2201.04775, 2022. [Online]. Available: https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.04775
Summary: The paper examines non-Gaussian self-similar solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations, building on the class of solutions from Cannone-Planchon (1996). It studies self-similar solutions to the 1D Burgers equation, identifying not only the known source-type solution but also a new kink-type solution represented by Kummer's function $M$. For the 2D Navier-Stokes equations, alongside the classical Burgers vortex, the authors derive another solution to the related Fokker-Planck equation, which serves as a 'conjugate' to the Burgers vortex in analogy to the kink solution. The asymptotic properties of this new class of solutions are analyzed, and the potential implications for the 3D Navier-Stokes equations are discussed. Additionally, the paper explores how self-similar solutions, such as the source-type solution in 3D, can inform our understanding of more general solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations.

Citation: T. Orponen and P. Shmerkin, "On the Hausdorff dimension of Furstenberg sets and orthogonal projections in the plane," Duke Mathematical Journal, vol. 172, no. 18, pp. 3559–3632, 2023. [Online]. Summary:
This paper investigates the minimal Hausdorff dimension of $(s,t)$-Furstenberg sets $K \subset \mathbb{R}^2$, that is, sets which intersect a family of lines $\mathcal{L}$ (with $\dim_{\mathrm{H}}\mathcal{L} \geq t$) in subsets of dimension at least $s$. The authors prove that for $s \in (0,1)$ and $t \in (s,2]$, such sets must have dimension at least $2s + \epsilon$ for some $\epsilon > 0$ depending only on $s$ and $t$. This result improves upon Wolff's previous lower bound of $2s$, particularly when $s > 1/2$ and $t = 1$. Moreover, the same approach yields an improved version of Kaufmans projection theorem: for an analytic $K \subset \mathbb{R}^2$ with $\dim_{\mathrm{H}} K = t$, the set of directions $e$ such that the orthogonal projection $\pi_e(K)$ has dimension at most $s$ satisfies
$$
\dim_{\mathrm{H}} \{e \in S^1 : \dim_{\mathrm{H}} \pi_e(K) \leq s\} \leq s - \epsilon,
$$
with $\epsilon$ depending on $s$ and $t$. The methodology involves a refined induction on scales, multi-scale decomposition, and a reduction to discrete incidence geometry of tubes, providing new insights into the structure and dimensionality of such fractal sets and their projections.

Citation: D.-J. Feng, "Dimension of invariant measures for affine iterated function systems," Duke Mathematical Journal, vol. 172, no. 4, pp. 701–774, 2023. [Online]. Summary: Let $\{S_i\}_{i\in \Lambda}$ be a finite contracting affine iterated function system (IFS) on $\mathbb{R}^d$. Let $(\Sigma,\sigma)$ denote the two-sided full shift over the alphabet $\Lambda$, and $\pi:\Sigma\to \mathbb{R}^d$ be the coding map associated with the IFS. We prove that the projection of an ergodic $\sigma$-invariant measure on $\Sigma$ under $\pi$ is always exact dimensional, and its Hausdorff dimension satisfies a Ledrappier-Young type formula. Furthermore, the result extends to average contracting affine IFSs. This completes several previous results and answers a folklore open question in the community of fractals. Some applications are given to the dimension of self-affine sets and measures.

Zhu, "Upper estimates for the Hausdorff dimension of the temporal attractor for a 3D Keller-Segel-Navier-Stokes system," Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society, vol. 153, no. 5, pp. 1983–1997, 2025. The paper studies the chemotaxis-fluid system
\[
\begin{cases}
n_t + u \cdot \nabla n = \Delta n - \nabla \cdot (n \nabla c), \\
c_t + u \cdot \nabla c = \Delta c - n c, \\
u_t + (u \cdot \nabla) u = \Delta u + \nabla P + n \nabla \Phi, \quad \nabla \cdot u = 0,
\end{cases}
\]
which describes aerobic bacteria interacting with a fluid through transport and buoyancy, posed on a three-dimensional, convex domain $\Omega$. Since this matches the sharpest known upper bound for the temporal singularity set of the unperturbed NavierStokes equations, the result is essentially optimal unless breakthroughs occur in the regularity theory for NavierStokes equations.

Citation: A. Sarfraz, "Hausdorff dimension of Julia sets of unicritical correspondences," Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society, vol. 151, no. 2, pp. 725–734, 2023. [Online]. Available: https://www.ams.org/journals/proc/2023-151-02/S0002-9939-2022-16125-5/S0002-9939-2022-16125-5.pdf
Summary: This paper studies Julia sets of the holomorphic correspondence $z \mapsto z^{\beta} + c$ for rational $\beta>1$ (where $\beta=p/q$ in lowest terms), focusing on cases where the Julia set $J$ forms a locally eventually onto hyperbolic repeller. Using the thermodynamic formalism and transfer (RuellePerronFrobenius) operator, the authors prove that the Hausdorff dimension of $J$ is bounded above by the unique zero of the pressure function $P(t)$ associated with the system. Their main theorem states that if $J$ is a hyperbolic repeller, then $\dim_H(J) \leq t_0$, where $t_0$ solves $P(t_0)=0$, and specifically for $q^2 < p$ and small $|c|$, the Julia set has zero Lebesgue measure. These findings generalize previous results from polynomial dynamical systems to a broader family of unicritical correspondences, sharpening known dimension estimates and establishing the absence of positive measure in new parameter regimes. The discussion points towards further refinements for non-hyperbolic settings and conjectural extensions to wider classes, while the conclusion emphasizes the novel bounding technique and its consequence that such Julia sets typically have Hausdorff dimension strictly less than two for the parameters considered.

Citation: J. M. Fraser, D. C. Howroyd, A. Käenmäki, and H. Yu, "On the Hausdorff dimension of microsets," Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society, vol. 147, no. 11, pp. 4607–4617, 2019. [Online]. Available: https://www.ams.org/journals/proc/2019-147-11/S0002-9939-2019-14613-X/
Summary: The paper investigates the relationship between the Hausdorff dimensions of microsets and the dimensions of the original set. This work is driven by the broader aim of understanding which geometric properties of a set are encoded at the level of its tangents.

Citation: M. Myllyoja, "Hausdorff dimension of limsup sets of isotropic rectangles in Heisenberg groups," Journal of Fractal Geometry, vol. 11, no. 3/4, pp. 219–246, 2024. [Online]. Available: https://ems.press/journals/jfg/articles/14298232

Summary: The paper establishes conditions on a general family of orthogonal projections $P_{\lambda} : \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m, \lambda \in \Lambda,$ that ensure the Hausdorff dimension formula $\dim A \cap P_{\lambda}^{-1}\{u\} = s - m$ holds generically for measurable sets $A \subset \mathbb{R}^n$ with positive and finite $s$-dimensional Hausdorff measure ($s > m$) and positive lower density. Citation: K. Héra, T. Keleti, and A. Máthé, "Hausdorff dimension of unions of affine subspaces and of Furstenberg-type sets," Journal of Fractal Geometry, vol. 6, no. 3, pp. 263–284, 2019. [Online]. Available: https://ems.press/journals/jfg/articles/16321
Summary: This paper establishes that for any $1 \le k < n$ and $s \le 1$, the union of any nonempty $s$-Hausdorff dimensional family of $k$-dimensional affine subspaces of $\mathbb{R}^n$ must have Hausdorff dimension $k + s$. Citation: W. Bergweiler and A. Tsantaris, "Hausdorff dimension in quasiregular dynamics," Israel Journal of Mathematics, vol. 265, pp. 429–465, 2025. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1007/s11856-024-2664-3
